awd_titl_txt: Exposure to Biracial Americans and Changes in Essentialist Beliefs
awd_abstract_narration:
The number of Americans who self-identify as belonging to more than one race has grown to over 9 million, emerging as one of the fastest growing demographic groups in the United States.  There has been much discussion, in both academic disciplines and public forums, about the impact of mixed-race population growth on peoples' stereotypes and prejudices about racial groups, and particularly how biracially-identified individuals may challenge underlying beliefs about racial categories themselves. 

This project will examine the impact of exposure to biracial identified, racially ambiguous individuals on White perceivers' beliefs about social categories. Using a naturalistic longitudinal study of recent arrivals to Hawaii (a largely multiracial context) and a series of laboratory experiments in the U.S. mainland, this project tests whether Whites' exposure to biracially identified individuals causes Whites to believe that society is moving away from biological, discrete views of racial categories and to subsequently decrease their personal endorsement of essentialism. Moreover, this proposal tests two seemingly contradictory consequences of essentialist belief change. On the one hand, essentialism reduction should lead to more favorable attitudes towards racial minorities and less use of social categories in judgment. On the other hand, recognizing that society has become less essentialist may increase perceptions of racial equity and racial progress and lower support for diversity policies (e.g., affirmative action). 

By identifying the positive and negative consequences of reduced essentialism and the conditions under which reductions occur, this project will aid in identifying potential intergroup interventions that involve naturally occurring challenges to essentialism (e.g., biracial exposure) and help us understand how they operate (e.g., through changing beliefs about societal norms and expanding individuals' cognitive flexibility).

por.por_cntn:
The number of Americans who self-identify as belonging to more than one race has increased to over 9 million, emerging as one of the fastest growing demographic groups in the United States. There has been much discussion, in both academic disciplines and public forums, about the impact of mixed-race population growth on peoples' stereotypes and prejudices about racial groups, and particularly how changes in racial diversity may challenge underlying beliefs about racial categories themselves. 

Using laboratory experiments and collecting data on interracial contact over time, we found that exposure to racially ambiguous individuals led White Americans living in the mainland U.S. to believe that society was moving away from biological, discrete views of racial categories and to subsequently decrease their personal endorsement of essentialism. Using a naturalistic longitudinal study of recent White arrivals to Hawaii (a largely multiracial context), we also found that time spent in Hawaii led to less endorsement of race essentialism, as a result of an increasingly diverse social network. In addition, we found that declines in essentialism were associated with decreases in modern racism and a greater preference for group equality. Moreover, lower race essentialism was found to predict greater cognitive flexibility in both social domains (i.e., the use of biracial categories) and non-social domains (i.e., the ability to view objects as belonging to non-prototypical categories).  Evidence also suggested that non-social experiences (e.g., fluid movements of the body) can increase cognitive flexibility, which in turn reduces essentialist beliefs about race, suggesting bidirectional causal relationships between cognitive flexibility and racial essentialism.

Important individual differences (e.g., racial identification of perceivers, racial make-up of perceiver’s neighborhoods) and features of biracial targets (e.g., physical racial ambiguity, racial identification of targets) were identified that influence the impact of exposure to racial diversity. For example, exposure to racially ambiguous individuals may be more likely to produce reductions in essentialism when exposed to people who identify as biracial and when White perceivers are less identified with their racial group membership. In addition, the results of this project suggested that the racial diversity of people’s neighborhoods influences their processing of racially ambiguous faces suggesting that the consequences of ambiguity exposure on interracial attitudes may also depend on where people live.

While we found little direct evidence that declines in essentialism from exposure to biracial targets simultaneously led to increased perceptions of racial equity and declined social support for policies such as affirmative action (our original prediction), we did find that situational features of minority and mixed-race targets (e.g., being a first generation student) influence the implementation of affirmative action, such that affirmative action policy support may be greater when exposed to stereotype consistent (e.g., first generation students) or prototypical exemplars of minority categories (e.g., minority monoracial individuals). While we found that racial essentialism change was associated with expected improvement in egalitarian attitudes, we found little evidence that essentialism change transferred across social categories (i.e., declines in racial essentialism were not associated with declines in gender essentialism). We have preliminary evidence, however, that similar factors (i.e., gender norms and gender category ambiguity) undermine gender essentialism.

In sum, we identified both situational aspects of exposure (e.g., identification of individuals with mixed-race ancestry, their physical appearance, and socioeconomic status) as well individual level differences (e.g., racial identification of perceivers as well as their neighborhood characteristics) that may influence how racial diversity affects conceptions of racial categories as discrete and biological. In addition, this project demonstrated how subtly conveyed social norms about race influence how White individuals perceive racial categories and the social boundaries between different racial groups. Moreover, this research revealed how cognitive expansion may both produce and results from changes in essentialism.
